content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would opt for strategy R {R}. The reason is that the potential gains from choosing R are significantly higher when my opponent chooses B, which happens if we alternate choices (RRB... or BRBR...) throughout the game.

In the worst-case scenario where our choices are always opposite (BB), I would still earn 20$ per round, resulting in a total of 1500$ for all 75 rounds. In contrast, if my opponent consistently chooses R and I stick to B, I would only earn 900$ in the worst-case scenario.

However, by choosing R, there's a chance that our choices align, and we both get 45$ per round, resulting in a total of 3375$ for all 75 rounds. Therefore, it seems like strategy R {R} offers better potential returns, even though the risk of getting 0$ is higher when facing an opponent who also chooses R.

I will choose B {B}. In this scenario, by choosing R first and facing an opponent who also chose R, we both earned 45$ in the previous round. Now, if we continue to alternate our choices (BBRR...), each round will result in a payoff of 20$. Over the course of 75 rounds, the total earnings would be 1500$, which is still better than the worst-case scenario when both players choose B consistently (900$).
